https://prez.dev/description.@value: The study of conventional (carbonate and clastic) petroleum systems that contain hydrocarbon accumulations. Conventional petroleum systems are accesible by standard oilfield techniques and typically do not require advanced drilling, completions, and reservoir stimulation methods. (Definition and scopeNote collated and adapted from: Selley & Sonnenburg, 2015; Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary & Wikipedia, both accessed 18.06.2020).
The subject is an instance of a class.
The defininition of the subject resource.
An idea or notion; a unit of thought
Relates a concept to a concept that is more general in meaning
A statement or formal explanation of the meaning of a concept

skos:exactMatch is used to link two concepts, indicating a high degree of confidence that the concepts can be used interchangeably across a wide range of information retrieval applications. skos:exactMatch is a transitive property, and is a sub-property of skos:closeMatch
A note about the past state/use/meaning of a concept
Relates a resource (for example a concept) to a concept scheme in which it is included
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language

A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The study of conventional (carbonate and clastic) petroleum systems that contain hydrocarbon accumulations and are defined as those where buoyant forces keep hydrocarbons in place below the sealing caprocks and permit petroleum (oil and/or natural gas) to flow readily from reservoirs into wellbores; i.e. are accessible by standard oilfield techniques and typically do not require advanced drilling, completions, and reservoir stimulation methods. Studies of conventional reservoir include assessment of rock properties, particularly porosity, permeability and compressibility, and of the timing and mechanism of trap formation, as petroleum source rocks, reservoir rocks, impermeable caprocks/seals must form in a favourable sequence to allow accumulation in reservoir rocks (following petroleum generation in source rocks and its ensuing migration therefrom).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

Studies of conventional reservoir include assessment of rock properties, particularly porosity, permeability and compressibility, and of the timing and mechanism of trap formation, as petroleum source rocks, reservoir rocks, impermeable caprocks/seals must form in a favourable sequence to allow accumulation in reservoir rocks (following petroleum generation in source rocks and its ensuing migration therefrom).
